description: [Status: stable] [Name: unconventional-import-alias] [Message: {name} should be imported as {asname}] What it does Checks for imports that are typically imported using a common convention, like import pandas as pd, and enforces that convention. Why is this bad? Consistency is good. Use a common convention for imports to make your code more readable and idiomatic. For example, import pandas as pd is a common convention for importing the pandas library, and users typically expect Pandas to be aliased as pd. Example import pandas Use instead: import pandas as pd

lint.flake8-import-conventions.aliases.option_description:
The conventional aliases for imports. These aliases can be extended by
the extend-aliases option.



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff.lint.flake8-import-conventions.aliases]
# Declare the default aliases.
altair = "alt"
"matplotlib.pyplot" = "plt"
numpy = "np"
pandas = "pd"
seaborn = "sns"
scipy = "sp"



[lint.flake8-import-conventions.aliases]
# Declare the default aliases.
altair = "alt"
"matplotlib.pyplot" = "plt"
numpy = "np"
pandas = "pd"
seaborn = "sns"
scipy = "sp"

lint.flake8-import-conventions.extend-al.option_description:
A mapping from module to conventional import alias. These aliases will
be added to the aliases mapping.



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff.lint.flake8-import-conventions.extend-aliases]
# Declare a custom alias for the `dask` module.
"dask.dataframe" = "dd"



[lint.flake8-import-conventions.extend-aliases]
# Declare a custom alias for the `dask` module.
"dask.dataframe" = "dd"
